</pubtime> <title>Direct evidence of a biophysical retention mechanism for coral reef fish larvae </title> <geoform>Spreadsheet, Images, Document, Model </geoform> <serinfo> <sername>Limnology and Oceanography </sername> <issue>49(6):1964-1979 </issue> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace>Alberta, Canada </pubplace> <publish>American Society of Limnology and Oceanography </publish> </pubinfo> </origin> <origin>Olson, D.B. </origin> <pubdate>2002 </pubdate> <pubtime>Unknown </pubtime> <title>Multivariate objective analysis fo the coastal circulation of Barbados, West Indies: implication for larval transport </title> <geoform>journal article </geoform> <serinfo> <sername>Deep-Sea Research I </sername> <issue>49(8):1363-1386 </issue> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace>St. Louis, MO </pubplace> <publish>Elsevier B.V. </publish> </pubinfo> <onlink>http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/groups/larval-fish/Publications.cfm </onlink> <lworkcit> <citeinfo> <origin>Cowen, R.K., </origin> <origin>Spongaugle, S. </origin> <origin>Paris, C.B., </origin> <origin>Fortuna, J.L., </origin> <origin>Lwiza, K.M.M., </origin> <origin>Dorsey, S. </origin> <pubdate>2003 </pubdate> <pubtime>Unknown </pubtime> <title>Impact of North Brazil Current rings on local circulation and coral reef fish recruitment to Barbados, West Indies </title> <geoform>book chapter </geoform> <serinfo> <sername>Elsevier Oceanography Series </sername> <issue>68 </issue> </serinfo> <pubinfo> <pubplace>St. Louis, MO </pubplace> <publish>Elsevier, B.V. </publish> </pubinfo> <othercit>22 pages in: Interhemispheric Water Exchange in the Atlantic Ocean. eds., G.J. Goni and P.M. Rizzoli. 524 pp. </othercit> <onlink>http://www.rsmas.miami.edu/gorups/larval-fish/Publications.cfm </onlink> </citeinfo> </lworkcit> </citeinfo> </lworkcit> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>We examine the hypothesis that reef fish larvae have some direct influence on their own dispersal and ability to recruit to their natal reef by tracking cohorts of bicolor damselfish (Stegastes partitus) from hatching to settlement onto the reef, about 30d later. We conducted high-resolution sampling during two consecutive years in a small area (15 km x 20 km) off the west coast of Barbados, extending from depths of 0 to 100 m. Observations of discrete stage-specific larval patches of mean size of 29.4 and 13.2 km^2 for preflexion (1-5-d old) and flexion/postflexion (>5-d old) stages extending ca. 30 m in the vertical indicated that larvae intitially dispersing as patches tend to stay in coherent patches throughout their pelagic duration. Highest concentrations of preflexion larvae within a patch were in the upper 20 m, while those of older larvae were always deeper. Downward migration of about 60 m throughout ontogeny within stratified currents represented a retention mechanism for locally spawned larvae. Most of the variability in estimated retention rates between daily cohorts occurred during the earliest stages as a result of the dynamic nature of surface currents experienced by larvae prior to the onset of vertical migration. Differences in residence time between experiments were consistent with observed intermonthly variability in recruitment strength, implying that pelagic processes can explain recruitment rates. These results provide empirical evidence for larval retnetion of coral reef fishes and stress the role of active behavior in larval transport. </abstract> <purpose>"Our main objective was to investigate the mechanism by which coral reef fish larvae may maximize their return to the settlement habitat of the natal population. For this purpose, we needed to dermine the role of larval behavior in controlling dispersal and horizontal advection and it relationship to the island-scale flow patterns." </purpose> </descript> </onlink> </citeinfo> </toolcite> </tool> </idinfo> <spdoinfo> <indspref>Barbados, West Indies, the Lesser Antilles, vertical layers in the water column at 20-m intervals from 0-100 m. </indspref> <direct>Raster </direct> <rastinfo> <rasttype>Point </rasttype> </rastinfo> </spdoinfo> <spref> <horizsys> <geograph> <latres>0.15 </latres> <longres>0.15 </longres> <geogunit>Decimal degrees </geogunit> </geograph> </horizsys> <vertdef> <depthsys> <depthdn>Local surface </depthdn> <depthres>1.0 </depthres> <depthdu>meters </depthdu> <depthem>Attribute values </depthem> </depthsys> </vertdef> </spref> <eainfo> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>Sampling </enttypl> <enttypd>Species, general area, study site, previous sampling programs, and biophysical sampling schemes were created for this project. </enttypd> <enttypds>From publication. </enttypds> </enttyp> <attr> <attrlabl>Study species selection </attrlabl> <attrdef>"A focal species, the bicolor damselfish Stegastes partituts (Poey) (Pomacentridae), was chosen to serve as a proxy for identifying general mechanisms in reef fish recruitment. This species is one of the most ubiquitous inhabitant of coral reefs in the western central Atlantic." </attrdef> <attrdefs>From publication </attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>Stage 1 S. partitus larvae </edomv> <edomvd>"50-60% of stage 1 ... larvae were located in the upper 20 m within the offshore flow region, ... [and] there were fluctuations in the magnitude of post-hatching pulses, with peak densitites in 1996." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication. </edomvds> </edom> <edom> <edomv>Stage 2 S. partitus larvae </edomv> <edomvd>"...Most stage 2 [larvae] are further down into the onshore flow region. ... As expected by physical diffusion and natural mortality acting concurrently upon pelagic larvae, stage 2 larvae were less abundant and not confined to the coast." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication. </edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea>19960508 </begdatea> <begdatea>19970429 </begdatea> <enddatea>19960603 </enddatea> <enddatea>19970527 </enddatea> <attrmfrq>3-5 d. for entire domain </attrmfrq> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>General sampling scheme </attrlabl> <attrdef>"Our premise was to initiate sampling during the stage of the lunar cycle when peak hatching normally occurs based on simultaneous monitoring of the daily reproductive output ... In principle, this allowed us to track a montly cohort of fishes throughout their pelagic larval stage." </attrdef> <attrdefs>From publication </attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>There are no values for the general sampling scheme. </udom> </attrdomv> <begdatea>19960508 </begdatea> <begdatea>19970429 </begdatea> <enddatea>19960603 </enddatea> <enddatea>19970527 </enddatea> <attrmfrq>3-5 d. for entire domain </attrmfrq> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Study site </attrlabl> <attrdef>"...The experiments took place on the western shore of Barbados in the area of high larval concentration and were limited to an area of 15 x 20 km ... The island-scale flow at Barbados is dominated by a combination of large fluctuations in current direction (typically reversing twice every 20 d....) and intrusions of low-salinity water entrained by North Brazil Current (NBC) rings originating from the Amazon ... External forcing by NBC rings is characterized by a strong signal on the local circulation ..., with a concomitant increased variability in local recruitment cycles ..." </attrdef> <attrdefs>From publication </attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>"...The experiments took place on the western shore of Barbados in the area of high larval concentration and were limited to an area of 15x20 km." </udom> </attrdomv> <begdatea>19960508 </begdatea> <begdatea>19970429 </begdatea> <enddatea>19960603 </enddatea> <enddatea>19970527 </enddatea> <attrmfrq>3-5 d. for entire domain </attrmfrq> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Previous ichthyoplankton work </attrlabl> <attrdef>"Previous extensive plankton surveys around Barbados in 1990-1991 identifiedan area of high larval concentrations that was persistent in spite of the variable nature of the incident flow ... The island-scale flow at Barbados is dominated by a combination of large fluctuations in current direction (typically reversing twice every 20 d. ...) and intrusions of low-salinity water entrained by North Brazil Current (NBC) rings originating from the Amazon ... External forcing by NBC rings is characterized by a strong signal on the local circulation ..., with a concomitant increased variability in local recruitment cycles ..." </attrdef> <attrdefs>From publication </attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>Previously identified area of larval concentration </edomv> <edomvd>15 x 20 km area on the western shore of Barbados </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea>19960508 </begdatea> <begdatea>19970429 </begdatea> <enddatea>19990603 </enddatea> <enddatea>19970527 </enddatea> <attrvai> <attrva>1.0 </attrva> <attrvae>Lowest attribute value in Km. </attrvae> </attrvai> <attrmfrq>3-5 d. for entire domain </attrmfrq> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Biophysical sampling </attrlabl> <attrdef>"Integration of physical and biological processes was key to this study and was achieved by conducting a serie of high-resolution, sequential hydrographic and planktonic surveys during two cruises on the R/V Seward Johnson carried in 1996 and 1997. Each cruise started in spring and lasted approcimatley 1 month ... and was tiemd to start near peak hatching (third month) of the bicolor damselfish." </attrdef> <attrdefs>From publication </attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>CTD casts </edomv> <edomvd>Day 1: 26 CTD casts/24 hr. were performed, through an alongshore grid pattern </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> <edom> <edomv>ADCP profiles </edomv> <edomvd>Day 1: "...Velocity profiles (4-m vertical bin size, averaged every 4 min)" were collected.Day 2: "ADCP profiles continued to be recorded concurrently with MOCNESS tows." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> <edom> <edomv>MOCNESS tows </edomv> <edomvd>Day 2: "...Vertically discrete plankton samples were collected at 22 stations using a 1-m^2 mutliple-opening-closing net and environmental sensing system (MOCNESS) fitted with six nets of 333-micro-m mesh. ... Sampling was carried out during 24 h (12-h day and 12-h night), covering the domain in a zigzag pattern ... Each station was sampled with five nets at 20-m increments wihtin the upper 100 m ... Each net was towed at ~2 knots in an oblique and upward fashion for f min in each stratum, resulting in a volume filtered of approximately 250 m^3 per net."Day 3: "During day 3 of the 1997 cruise, a 10-m^2 MOCNESS fitted with five nets of 500-micro-m mesh was used to capture late developmental stages ... The shoreward sations were sampled with four nets at 20-m increments within the upper 80 m during the night hours." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> <edom> <edomv>GPS drifters </edomv> <edomvd>Day 3: "...Three to eight satellite-tracked, global positioning system drifters equipped with standard holey-sock droges (1-m diameter, 10-m long) were released offshore in clusters at various depth (2 m, 15 m, 50 m) and tracked within the study domain for up to 12 h to measure eddy diffusivity ..." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea>19960508 </begdatea> <begdatea>19970429 </begdatea> <enddatea>19960603 </enddatea> <enddatea>19970527 </enddatea> <attrmfrq>3-5 d. for entire domain </attrmfrq> </attr> </detailed> <detailed> <enttyp> <enttypl>ISLAFIT Model </enttypl> <enttypd>An "In situ larval fish transport (ISLAFIT) [model was created] ... to reproduce the dynamic habitat of the larvae ... This optimal statistical technique was used to remove noise from scattered sampling and generated flow fields ..." </enttypd> <enttypds>From publication. </enttypds> </enttyp> <attr> <attrlabl>In situ larval fish transport (ISLAFIT) </attrlabl> <attrdef>"To reproduce the dynamic habitat of the larvae, in situ current velocities were reconstructed from multivariate objective analysis of the CTD and ADCP data (temperature, salinity, and total currents) ... This optimal statistical technique was used to remove noise from scattered sampling and generated flow fields ... this 30-2 coastal circulation model operated at the same spatial and temporal scales as the biological processes and was used to track virtual larvae." </attrdef> <attrdefs>From publication </attrdefs> <attrdomv> <udom>Flow fields were "generated ... in a regular mesh (12x12 grid), integrated every 20 m on five horizontal planes ... a total of eight, five-layer Eularian maps of horizontal currents were produced from each sampling cycle. A 6-h step was used to interpolate the currents between sampling cycles while the current from the last sampling cycle was maintained constant for 48 h, resulting in a continuous 30-d time series for each sampling experiment." </udom> </attrdomv> <begdatea>19960508 </begdatea> <begdatea>19970429 </begdatea> <enddatea>19960603 </enddatea> <enddatea>19970527 </enddatea> <attrmfrq>3-5 d. for entire domain </attrmfrq> </attr> <attr> <attrlabl>Retention rates </attrlabl> <attrdef>"Larval retention rates were calculated as a postprocess of the modeled larval tracking output from ISLAFIT with two main goals. First, retention rates were used to quantify the effect of active behavior (i.e., vertical migration) versus passive transport of reef fish larvae. Second, they were used to estimate the fate of hatching events observed on the western shore of Barbados by comparing the changes of modeled retention rates with observed differences in settlement strength between experiments." </attrdef> <attrdefs>From publication. </attrdefs> <attrdomv> <edom> <edomv>Retention </edomv> <edomvd>The "... daily percentage of tracers (or virtual larvae) remaining within the study area per 20-m strata or within the entire domain (0-1000 m)." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> <edom> <edomv>Water residence time </edomv> <edomvd>"Water residence time ... was ... calculated ... by releasing a total of 15,000 tracers on a regular mesh of 30 locations across the 12x12 grid in each of the five horizontal layers. Model runs at those fixed depths are conducted for 20 consecutive days, and the distribution of residence times is represented as an average of all runs or as a maximum value among all runs." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> <edom> <edomv>Daily hatching variability </edomv> <edomvd>"To quantify the oceanographic component in transport variability between yearly cruises, daily hatching variability was homogenized by simulating alongshore hatching pulses by releasing simultaneously six patches of 1,000 tracers each along the coat. Releases were always initiated at the surface (0-20-m layer) and tracked until the end of the 29-d sampling period each year. Patch release was performed gradually throughout the first hatching day (1/4 of the tracers are released every 6-h for the 24-h period)." </edomvd> <edomvds>From publication </edomvds> </edom> </attrdomv> <begdatea>19960508 </begdatea> <begdatea>19970429 </begdatea> <enddatea>19960603 </enddatea> <enddatea>19970527 </enddatea> <attrmfrq>3-5 d. for entire domain </attrmfrq> </attr> </detailed> </eainfo> <distinfo> <distrib> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntper>Dr. Claire Paris-Limouzy </cntper> <cntorg>University of Miami -
